title: Boy paralysed when dog pulled cushion from under him as he lay on the sofa
text:
Harvey Leyland suffered to mini-strokes and a spinal stroke after falling onto a tiled floor at home (Picture: Mercury Press)

A teenager has been left unable to move any of his body apart from his right index finger after one of his dogs pulled a cushion out from under his head.

Harvey Leyland, 17, was lying down when Hugo, a British bulldog, pulled the cushion out from under him, causing him to fall and land headfirst on a tiled floor.

Immediately after the accident he went upstairs to rest but suffered a seizure moments later. His brother Bradley heard what happened and summoned help at their home in Wigan.

When paramedics found him seven minutes later he was struggling to breathe and could not talk so he was taken to hospital and put into an induced coma for four days.

Doctors at Salford Royal Hospital found Harvey had suffered two mini-strokes and a spinal stroke that resulted in injury to his vertebrae.

Harvey was put into a coma for four days after being admitted to Salford Royal Hospital (Picture: Mercury Press)

Harvey, left, pictured with brother Bradley, right, who discovered him having a seizure in his bedroom (Picture: Mercury Press)

His mother Angela, 57, said: ‘I was out at the time it happened, I remember getting a call from my partner who told me to come home.

‘As soon as I learned what happened I rushed to the hospital. When I arrived I collapsed in the corridor, I couldn’t believe what was happening. My mind was racing.

‘I still feel like I’m in limbo. To see your child go from running around and being active to this is heart breaking.’

Harvey had to be fed through a tube for the first couple of weeks and was initially unable to speak.

Angela said: ‘I remember the first time he spoke to us after the accident. Nurses removed his tube and he said hello to the whole family. I broke down in tears of joy.

Harvey’s family are now raising money to adapt their house so that Harvey can come home (Picture: Mercury)

‘I thought he would start improving in other areas too, that everything would go back to normal. So to be told that he would be paralysed for life was another blow.’

Since the accident there has been little improvement with his body rejecting a catheter, but every step is seen as great progress.

Only four weeks ago he regained the ability to move his right index finger, but doctors say there are no signals going to the nerves in his legs or on the left side of his body.

He is now being looked after in Southport where he remains under observation and is receiving physiotherapy.

The family home has been deemed unsuitable for Harvey to return so the family have started a fundraising page to raise £50,000 for adaptations to be made.

Angela said: ‘Harvey just wants to come home and I’m desperate to make that happen. I just want my son back.

‘Because of his wheelchair he’d be trapped in his bedroom completely. I can’t let that happen to him. He’s only 17, it’s not fair on him.’

The funds would be used for a conversion of their garage and to convert the ground floor of their home so that it is open plan to avoid having to send Harvey to a care home.

Angela added: ‘He’s only 17 and because this kind of injury is rare for someone so young, he’d be in a home with older people.

‘He needs people his own age – he needs his family around him. Knowing that he might not be able to come home is having a negative effect on his mental health.

‘He’s a mummy’s boy, he’s more like a 14 year old at heart and he just wants to come home. It’s amazing the help we’ve received, but we still have a long way to go.’
